Background

First Energy Generation Corporation is a utility that generates electricity at  the Allegheny Energy Units 3, 4 & 5 Allegheny Supply Company, LLC in Springdale Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania. In order to reduce NOx air emissions, Springdale installed a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system back in 2002.  This system removes NOx by catalytically reacting NOx with Ammonia to form Nitrogen and water vapor.  The First Energy Springdale facility currently uses aqueous ammonia at a concentration of 19%. The facility intends to change the concentration of the aqueous ammonia stored at the site and used in the SCR emission control system from 19% to 29.5%, which is the reason for developing this RMP Plan. The process will be applicable to the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) rules due to the presence of 29.5 % Aqueous Ammonia.

The covered process includes: delivery tank truck unloading, storage, and SCR feed.  The aqueous ammonia storage tank maximum storage capacity is 18,398 gallons (90% capacity).  
 
Overview of the RMP Prevention Program 

The Springdale aqueous ammonia process is considered a Program 2 site by RMP rules.  Springdale uses a management of change and tri-annual compliance audit following EPA requirements.

Process protections are primarily those measures that will reduce, prevent or minimize a release from happening or, if it did happen, minimize the consequences of that threat.    These include:

¿	Procedures and plans such as operational SOPs and the Emergency Response Plan
¿	Training on operations, emergencies etc;
        -Operators of the systems covered by the RMP plan have refresher training at least every 3 years.
¿	Regular maintenance/SOPS;        
¿	During deliveries, attendance by the operator and driver are continuous until the delivery is complete;
¿	No ammonia delivery tank trucks stored on site other than those in the process of being unloaded;
¿	Onsite wireless communication;
¿	Onsite trucks

/vehicles for emergency transportation needs; 
¿	Selected drain and process valves are locked and capped when not in use;  
¿	Fire extinguishers; 
¿	Ammonia detectors/alarms;
¿	Main feed pump flow alarms/detector
¿	High level tank alarms 
¿	Secondary containment;         
¿	Storage tank design and inspections;
¿	Temperature/pressure indicators;
¿	Underground portion of pipeline clearly marked
¿	Incident investigation procedures; 

These are the major site security measures:

¿	Six-foot minimum height chain-link fence surrounds the site
¿	Guard house at main entrance staffed with a security guard 7AM-4PM M-F
¿	The Plant is staffed 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.
¿	All other gates are locked but may be opened in the event of emergency egress from the inside.
¿	Warning signs

It is the policy of FirstEnergy to assure the safe operation of the facility which is designed and built to good engineering practices that incorporate methods or principles in accordance with applicable industry standards.  Some of these standards include ASME Code for Power Piping, B31.1, and ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, Section VIII.   

Five Year Accident History

There have been no reportable accidents in the past five years.  

Emergency Response

There is a written emergency response plan that is coordinated with the Allegheny County Health Department, the Springdale LEPC and the local fire departments.  Selected site response personnel are HAZWOPER trained.    

Emergency response planning has long been an integral part of operations at Springdale.  Regulations under OSHA, EPA, and PADEP have required the site to develop and implement procedures to plan for and respond to emergency situations at the plant whether due to natural disasters, storms, chemical release exposure or harm/damage resulting from potentially flammable or explosive materials.  

The RMP Emergency Response Plan includes the following sections:
1.0	Facility Description

2.0	Emergency Response Plan Organization 
3.0	Emergency Coordinators
4.0	Emergency Coordinator's Duties and Responsibilities 
5.0	Ammonia Detector Action Levels
6.0	Chemical Release Emergency Procedures                                                                         
7.0	Internal and External Communications and Alarms Systems
8.0	Emergency Response Contacts
9.0	Worst-Case Release Modeling Results 
10.0	Evacuation Plan for Facility Personnel 
11.0	Emergency Medical Treatment                                                           
12.0    Emergency Response Equipment
13.0	Equipment Inspection and Monitoring Program
14.0	Employee Training Program
15.0	Emergency Response Plan Update Procedure
16.0	Plan Coordination

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As a result of the Process Hazard Analysis and Off-site Consequence Analysis the following changes were implemented:
¿ Included a section in the Emergency Response Program to shut down the Control Room HVAC system in the event of an ammonia release.
¿ Installation of ammonia detectors in the vicinity of the ammonia storage and unloading area and each SCR skid with visual and audio alarms for a 50 ppm concentration action level.
¿ Installation of bollards where ammonia pipeline travels underground and emerges aboveground to prevent pipeline impacts.
¿ Painting and installation of signage which labels the underground ammonia pipeline.
¿ Purchased and supplied additional escape air canisters in the Control Room and ammonia unloading area.
¿ Installation of a wind sock for instantaneous determination of wind direction for emergency planning purposes.
